game_description: Three fishing families simultaneously choosing between sustainable fishing (cooperate) or intensive fishing (defect) with collective resource at stake

matrix.T_temptation: Fish intensively while others conserve - maximum catch, no competition
matrix.R_reward: All conserve - lake recovers, sustainable long-term profits
matrix.P_punishment: All fish intensively - lake collapses, everyone loses
matrix.S_sucker: Conserve while others fish intensively - lose income and market share

contradiction_evidence: 'I'd love to save the lake' vs 'fishing double shifts'
concern for sustainability vs intensifying efforts
cheap_talk_evidence: 'I'd love to save the lake' - costless statement
blaming neighbors while doing same behavior
credible_signals: actually fishing double shifts - costly commitment to defection

equilibrium.reasoning: Each player has dominant strategy to fish intensively regardless of others' choices due to immediate financial pressures

risk.sensitivity: Lake ecosystem collapse destroys all players' long-term viability
risk.reasoning: Mutual defection leads to resource collapse - mutually assured destruction of fishing industry

prescription.mechanism_design: External enforcement or compensation fund - reduce Sucker payoff penalty through guaranteed income during conservation periods
prescription.player_a_advice: Form binding conservation pact with penalties for violations
prescription.player_b_advice: Coordinate on rotating fishing schedules to maintain some income while allowing recovery
prescription.mediator_advice: Implement quota system with tradeable permits or government buyout program during recovery period
prescription.victim_warning: All families claiming to want sustainability while actively preventing it - collective self-deception masking tragedy of commons

input_summary:
Tensions are rising in the coastal town of Oakhaven. The local lake has 
always supported the community, but yields are dropping fast. Marine 
biologists warn that the fish population is on the brink ...
